dn3:2.14.11.pli: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yāvatako ahosi bhagavatā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ārocesi.
dn3:2.14.11.eng: Then Ambaṭṭha informed Pokkharasāti of all they had discussed.

dn3:2.15.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca:

dn3:2.15.2.pli: “aho vata re amhākaṃ, paṇḍitaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ, bahussutaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ, tevijjaka, evarūpena kira, bho, puriso atthacarakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya.
dn3:2.15.2.eng: “Oh, our bloody fake scholar, our fake learned man, who pretends to be proficient in the three Vedas! A man who behaves like this ought, when their body breaks up, after death, to be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
dn3:2.15.2.comm: The diminutive ending for paṇḍitaka is the same as in samaṇaka, which Ambaṭṭha used of the Buddha. | For re (“bloody”), compare cara pi re at Bu Pc 70:1.35 and he je kāḷī at MN 21:9.13. Hard as the Buddha was on Ambaṭṭha, his own teacher was harder.

dn3:2.15.3.pli: Yadeva kho tvaṃ, ambaṭṭha, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ āsajja āsajja avacāsi, atha kho so bhavaṃ gotamo amhepi evaṃ upaneyya upaneyya avaca.
dn3:2.15.3.eng: It’s only because you repeatedly attacked the worthy Gotama like that that he kept bringing up charges against us!”
dn3:2.15.3.comm: Pokkharasāti shows his astuteness, for in many other dialogues the Buddha engaged with brahmins perfectly politely, as he does in the next sutta (DN 4).

dn3:2.15.4.pli: Aho vata re amhākaṃ, paṇḍitaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ, bahussutaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ, tevijjaka, evarūpena kira, bho, puriso atthacarakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyā”ti, kupito anattamano ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ padasāyeva pavattesi.
dn3:2.15.4.eng: Angry and upset, he kicked Ambaṭṭha over,
dn3:2.15.4.comm: Illustrating the lack of restraint of even a senior brahmin teacher.

dn3:2.15.5.pli: Icchati ca tāvadeva bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn3:2.15.5.eng: and wanted to go and see the Buddha right away.

dn3:2.16.1.pli: Atha kho te brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn3:2.16.1.eng: Then those brahmins said to Pokkharasāti,

dn3:2.16.2.pli: “ativikālo kho, bho, ajja samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn3:2.16.2.eng: “It’s much too late to visit the ascetic Gotama today.

dn3:2.16.3.pli: Svedāni bhavaṃ pokkharasāti samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.
dn3:2.16.3.comm: Given Pokkharasāti’s mood, this was probably a diplomatic move.

dn3:2.16.4.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā yāne āropetvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu ukkaṭṭhāya niyyāsi, yena icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍo tena pāyāsi.
dn3:2.16.4.eng: So Pokkharasāti had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home. Then he mounted a carriage and, with attendants carrying torches, set out from Ukkaṭṭhā for the forest near Icchānaṅgala.
dn3:2.16.4.comm: Khādanīya and bhojanīya are food categories commonly mentioned in Pali. Etymologically they stem from “hard and soft”. Bhojanīya is defined in Bu Pc 37:2.1.10 as grain, porridge, flour products, fish, and meat, thus being foods that are typically eaten cooked and “mooshed up” in with the fingers in the bowl. Khādanīya is not so readily defined, being essentially everything not included in other categories. But it would have included such “crunchy” things as fruit and vegetables, which may be eaten uncooked.

dn3:2.17.1.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn3:2.17.1.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot. He went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

dn3:2.17.2.pli: “āgamā nu khvidha, bho gotama, amhākaṃ antevāsī ambaṭṭho māṇavo”ti?
dn3:2.17.2.eng: “Master Gotama, has my resident pupil, the student Ambaṭṭha, come here?”

dn3:2.17.3.pli: “Āgamā kho te, brāhmaṇa, antevāsī ambaṭṭho māṇavo”ti.

dn3:2.17.4.pli: “Ahu pana te, bho gotama, ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
dn3:2.17.4.eng: “And did you have some discussion with him?”

dn3:2.17.5.pli: “Ahu kho me, brāhmaṇa, ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.

dn3:2.17.6.pli: “Yathākathaṃ pana te, bho gotama, ahu ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
dn3:2.17.6.eng: “And what kind of discussion did you have with him?”
dn3:2.17.6.comm: Pokkharasāti makes sure he hears both sides of the story.

dn3:2.17.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yāvatako ahosi ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ārocesi.
dn3:2.17.7.eng: Then the Buddha informed Pokkharasāti of all they had discussed.

dn3:2.17.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn3:2.17.8.eng: Then Pokkharasāti said to the Buddha,

dn3:2.17.9.pli: “bālo, bho gotama, ambaṭṭho māṇavo, khamatu bhavaṃ gotamo ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassā”ti.
dn3:2.17.9.eng: “Ambaṭṭha is a fool, worthy Gotama. Please forgive him.”
dn3:2.17.9.comm: So far has Ambaṭṭha fallen from the learned sage we were introduced to at the start of the sutta.

dn3:2.17.10.eng: “May the student Ambaṭṭha be happy, brahmin.”
dn3:2.17.10.comm: The Buddha bears no ill will. Sukhī hotu is one of the most recognizable Pali phrases, but in early texts it is spoken only a few times: by the Buddha at DN 21:1.8.8 and Snp 5.1:54.1; by Punabbasu’s Mother at SN 10.7:10.1; and by various women at Bu Ss 5:1.4.8.

dn3:2.18.1.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi.
dn3:2.18.1.eng: Then Pokkharasāti scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.

dn3:2.18.2.pli: Addasā kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
dn3:2.18.2.eng: He saw all of them except for two,

dn3:2.18.3.pli: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—

dn3:2.18.4.eng: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.

dn3:2.18.5.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

dn3:2.18.6.pli: “passati kho me ayaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
dn3:2.18.6.eng: “Pokkharasāti sees all the marks except for two,

dn3:2.18.7.pli: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—

dn3:2.18.8.eng: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”

dn3:2.18.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasa brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ.
dn3:2.18.9.eng: Then the Buddha used his psychic power to will that Pokkharasāti would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.

dn3:2.18.10.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ jivhāya chādesi.
dn3:2.18.10.eng: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.

dn3:2.19.2.pli: “samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi no aparipuṇṇehī”ti.
dn3:2.19.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.”

dn3:2.19.4.pli: “adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo ajjatanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn3:2.19.4.eng: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept today’s meal from me?”

dn3:2.20.1.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocesi:
dn3:2.20.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Pokkharasāti announced the time to him,

dn3:2.20.2.eng: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”

dn3:2.20.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn3:2.20.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Pokkharasāti together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.
dn3:2.20.3.comm: “Robed up” because inside the monastery, monks would normally wear just a lower robe, and would don the upper and (sometimes) outer robes when visiting a layperson’s home.

dn3:2.20.4.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi, māṇavakāpi bhikkhusaṅghaṃ.
dn3:2.20.4.eng: Then Pokkharasāti served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods, while his young students served the Saṅgha.

dn3:2.20.5.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn3:2.20.5.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Pokkharasāti took a low seat and sat to one side.

dn3:2.21.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnassa kho brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa bhagavā anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
dn3:2.21.1.eng: Then the Buddha taught him step by step, with

dn3:2.21.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ; kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
dn3:2.21.2.eng: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
dn3:2.21.2.comm: While all these teachings feature commonly in the suttas, there is no text that depicts this framework in detail.

dn3:2.21.3.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
dn3:2.21.3.eng: And when the Buddha knew that Pokkharasāti’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:

dn3:2.21.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
dn3:2.21.4.comm: This is the briefest expression of the four noble truths.

dn3:2.21.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
dn3:2.21.5.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

dn3:2.21.6.pli: evameva brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa tasmiññeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
dn3:2.21.6.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the brahmin Pokkharasāti:
dn3:2.21.6.comm: This indicates that he became a stream-enterer (sotāpanna), the first of four stages of Awakening. Such details of personal attainment are typically found in the narrative rather than the teaching attributed to the Buddha, and hence were added by redactors at some point. They vary considerably in different versions. In this case, the parallel at DA 20 says that he became a stream-enterer and later a non-returner. T 20 said that he understood the teaching and went for refuge, and agrees that he became a non-returner before his death.

dn3:2.21.7.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
dn3:2.21.7.comm: This is the insight into universal impermanence and dependent origination.

dn3:2.22.0.eng: 9. Pokkharasāti Declares Himself a Lay Follower

dn3:2.22.1.pli: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn3:2.22.1.eng: Then Pokkharasāti saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha,

dn3:2.22.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn3:2.22.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, just so has the worthy Gotama made the Teaching clear in many ways.

dn3:2.22.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho gotama, saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn3:2.22.4.eng: Together with my children, wives, retinue, and ministers, I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn3:2.22.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
dn3:2.22.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

dn3:2.22.6.pli: Yathā ca bhavaṃ gotamo ukkaṭṭhāya aññāni upāsakakulāni upasaṅkamati, evameva bhavaṃ gotamo pokkharasātikulaṃ upasaṅkamatu.
dn3:2.22.6.eng: Just as the worthy Gotama visits other devoted families in Ukkaṭṭhā, may he visit mine.
dn3:2.22.6.comm: When wandering for alms, mendicants would often roam randomly through the village (sapadānacārī). However if an invitation such as this were issued, the mendicant may visit that place for a meal. It was considered a special ascetic practice to refuse such invitations. The same invitation was issued by Lohicca to Mahākaccāna at SN 35.132:14.7.

dn3:2.22.7.pli: Tattha ye te māṇavakā vā māṇavikā vā bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhivādessanti vā paccuṭṭhissanti vā āsanaṃ vā udakaṃ vā dassanti cittaṃ vā pasādessanti, tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
dn3:2.22.7.eng: The brahmin boys and girls there will bow to you, rise in your presence, give you a seat and water, and gain confidence in their hearts. That will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
dn3:2.22.7.comm: Māṇavikā is also mentioned at MN 56:27.1 and Ud 2.6:1.3 of a young married woman; and at AN 5.192:8.5 of a baby being born. Thus it does not seem that it meant “female student of the Vedas”.

dn3:2.22.8.eng: “That’s nice of you to say, householder.”
dn3:2.22.8.comm: Kalyāṇaṁ vuccati is a politely ambiguous phrase. It is spoken twice elsewhere in the Pali, and both times the mendicant who said it immediately departed and never returned (SN 41.3:7.13, SN 41.4:6.7).
